s.text: Iwas struck by this proposition about a month ago when I spent some time with my son in Los Angeles.
There was a time, probably now past, when medium-price restaurants would advertise themselves as serving "home cooking."
And this sense of belonging made the food taste great.
My son thought the food was great; I thought it was only pretty good.
My son thought the food was great; I thought it was only pretty good.
My son thought the food was great; I thought it was only pretty good.
This was his club, and that made the food taste great.
My son thought the food was great; I thought it was only pretty good.
Food tastes enormously better when it is eaten in a place where you are accepted as a special person, special for something other than the color of your credit card.
